text: more than 450 people are now known to
have died after Sunday's powerful
earthquake in Iran nearly eight thousand
people have been injured officials have
called off the rescue operation saying
it's unlikely that more survivors will
be found the Iranian president Hassan
rouhani has visited the affected area as
Richard lists in our reports the
earthquake shook much of the Middle East
but this is where it did most damage
hundreds of people in South Polly's are
hard lost their lives
tens of thousands lost their homes many
of these buildings were built by the
government as cheap housing after the
war with Iraq in the 1980s the question
some here are asking is why did so many
collapse in an area long prone to
earthquakes visiting the town today
Iran's president pledged that anyone
who'd failed to follow proper building
standards would be held accountable but
for now he's focusing on the survivors
[Music]
will provide tents for those who need
them and give loans and grants to all
those whose houses were damaged and are
unsafe will give money to everyone who
needs temporary accommodation an
estimated 70,000 people need emergency
shelter helicopters are bringing them
supplies while many roads are still
blocked by landslides the challenge is
to keep these survivors healthy as the
winter temperatures continue to fall
this is another challenge for the
authorities the town's only hospital was
so badly damaged it's unusable more than
a thousand of the injured are being
treated at hospitals around the region
they're far from home and many won't
have houses to return to across the
border in Iraq hundreds were injured but
only a handful were killed aid agencies
there say they're ready to assist Iran
if needed
[Music]
across the border cipolla Sahab had to
be rebuilt after the war with Iraq now
it will have to be
built all over again Richard Lister BBC
news
